text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with demi-glaze that's right as far
as I'm concerned demi-glaze is the
mother of all mother sauces and by the
way that statement is going to make
culinary instructors all over the
country cringe because technically
demi-glace is not one of the five mother
sauces but the good news is nobody cares
the only thing anyone should care about
is the fact this is by far one of the
most delicious substances ever created
by man and I should mention this is
going to be a two-part video so what
you're about to see is just the first
half which I guess is appropriate since
demi means half but enough with the
French lesson let's go ahead and get
started and the first thing we're going
to need is some veal bones as in ten
pounds placed in a large roasting pan
and of course this is not something
you're going to see sitting around at
the supermarket you're actually going to
have to call a real butcher and tell
them you're making demi-glace and you
want ten pounds of veal bones and while
technically you can make a stock with
any kind of bones what works best for
demi-glace as those from around the
joints you know hips knees ankles it
besides the joints any kind of bone that
has Marilyn it is always a welcomed
addition and the reason is those have
the maximum amount of collagen which
will eventually turn into gelatin which
once reduced gives this sauce its famous
sticky rich luxurious texture so our
veal bones are ready for the oven but
they're not going in there alone oh no
we need a mirepoix so onto a lightly
oiled sheet pan I'm going to dump some
onions celery and carrots cut nice big
chunks and then before these go in the
oven we have to do one messy but
somewhat fun step we need to smear these
with tomato paste so I'm going to spoon
in one small can of tomato paste and
then we'll use their hands to smear it
all over and yes this is definitely
easier doing in a bowl as your
vegetables won't fly all over like mine
did here but of course then you got to
watch an extra bowl so I just do it in
the pan but suit yourself and then once
our aromatic vegetables have been
smeared with the tomato paste we will
transfer our bones and vegetables into a
450 degree oven until they're both very
well browned so the veggies are probably
going to take you about 45 minutes to an
hour and you'll know they're ready when
they look like this okay we don't want
to stop until the tips of the onions
start turning black and don't worry that
blackness is not going to cause any off
flavor and it's really going to help
give the demi-glace its signature
gorgeous color so those are looking good
and while we're waiting for our bones to
fully Brown let's transfer our roasted
vegetables along with any caramelization
from the bottom of
pan into a giant giant stockpot I
believe this is like 2024 cords
something like that but exact size
doesn't matter as long as you can fit in
10 pounds of bones these vegetables and
10 quarts of water which I'm going to
add now since I'm still waiting for my
bones to get a little browner so I'm
gonna go ahead and pour in 10 quarts of
nice cold fresh water please do not use
tepid stagnant water for this and please
do not turn on the heat yet all right is
very important your veal bones start in
cold water because that's going to help
extract the maximum amount of flavor and
by now my bones were nicely browned so
I'm going to pull those out take a look
and for me that ended up taking about an
hour and 15 minutes but you don't want
to rush this
all right however long it takes to get
them nice and beautifully brown like
this and then once your browned bones
look like my brown bones we can add
those to our stock pots so at this point
let's put our heat on the highest
setting because of course we have to
bring this up to a boil and because we
have so much in the pot that's going to
take a while so while we're waiting
let's go ahead and deglaze our roasting
pan which as you can see has a whole
bunch of Awesomeness caramelized onto
the bottom so what we'll do is we'll put
in a couple cups of cold water put this
over medium to medium-high heat and just
give it a little working over with a
spatula until all that amazing goodness
dissolves off the bottom and don't think
this step is optional many a cook have
gotten fired for forgetting this step
all right I'm exaggerating
maybe not fired but definitely screamed
at by a large angry chef which in a lot
of ways is worse since they usually get
way too close and kind of spit while
they're talking but anyway we definitely
are going to deglaze our pan and add
that to our stock pot and that believe
it or not is it don't even think of
putting any salt in this we are not
going to salt this until we use it and
I'm also not going to put in a bouquet
garni and once again the culinary
instructors are cringing but what I'm
doing here I call a modern pure
demi-glace and by modern I mean there's
no ruin volved nothing artificially
thicken this and by pure I mean it's
only made with water veal bones in
mirepoix
plus it's made of paste which is
necessary chemically to make the magic
work and I don't have time here but on
the blog you will read why I forgo the
traditional bundle of herbs and spices
so like I said we'll bring this up to a
boil or at least an enthusiastic simmer
over high heat and of course if you want
to skim some foam go ahead probably not
a bad idea but be real careful okay if
you're removing fat or foam you don't
even want to lose
drop of that precious liquid and then
like pretty much all stocks will reduce
our heat to low because what we want to
maintain is a very very gentle simmer
for like believe it or not 18 to 24
hours oh yeah this is gonna take a while
so don't just turn it on low and walk
away thick and it's going to be perfect
okay we'll want to check back and we
really want to precisely dial in that
temperature so we just have very small
almost tiny bubbles breaking through the
surface so you really really don't want
to cooking any more vigorously than this
and then like I said I'm going to cook
this for at least 18 hours which for
most normal people means overnight don't
worry if it's simmering this generally
it's going to be fine and approximately
18 hours later this is what you want to
see completely bare bones there should
be absolutely zero connective tissue
anywhere to be seen
all right all that collagen all that
bone marrow all that sticky goodness
should be dissolved completely into your
broth and at this point you might think
you're close to being done but you're
not
not even close so what we need to do at
this point is carefully remove all the
chunks into a strainer set over a bowl
and the reason we have our strainer set
over a bowl is because if there was ever
ever a time you were going to return the
accumulated juices back to a pot it's
this time and to give you an idea of how
precious this stuff is considered
there's many chefs that will actually
rinse those bones save the water that
runs off reduce that and add that back
into this so I'm not going to do that
here but just make it a point so like I
said remove everything you can and when
you think it's dripped as much as it can
drip you can pour that back into your
pot and the reason we only have to worry
about the big chunks is because we're
going to strain this at the end so don't
worry if you see a little piece of this
or a little piece of that swimming
around we will strain that out after the
reduction step also known as the next
step so once all that stuff's been
removed we're going to go ahead and
crank our heat back up to high bring
this back to a boil and continue cooking
until it reduces down to just a gallon
or less okay I'm going to try to reduce
this down somewhere between three and
four quarts and when it seems like it's
getting down pretty close to where you
want of course you're going to reduce
your heat so it doesn't burn because if
it did that would be like the second
worst day of your life I'm assuming
something really bad has happened to you
that would be worse but that would be
horrible so be careful when you get near
the end again if you want to skim a
little foam or fat from the top feel
free but
don't lose any Demi after you strain
this and it's cold it's very very easy
to get the fat off the top and if you're
wondering how I know when it's down to
three or four quarts well because I kind
of know how big the pot is but if you
don't before you start just pour a
gallon of water in your pot and check
the level I know that's pretty
scientific but anyway I reduce mine down
at which point is ready to strain and
cool so we'll pass that through a fine
strainer and what's left I call
demi-glaze and as you can see my eyes
were pretty good I got just over three
quarts and don't worry about that thin
shiny film that forms on the top nobody
knows what that is but it's not a
problem I'm just going to stir it in and
pretend I never saw and by the way the
exact amount that you reduce this is
kind of irrelevant since you can always
add water back in or reduce it more to
concentrate and I'm very very important
before we put this away we want to make
sure you chill this down with an ice
bath although I'm not using ice I'm use
these ice packs I'm saving the cubes for
my Manhattan's but somehow someway
cool your Demi down and once you get
that down to a least room temperature
you can pop the top on and we will place
that in the refrigerator until it's
thoroughly chilled at which point this
